column1: '''''asëa''''' is a [[Quenya]] word which also constitutes the first element of the plant name ''[[asëa aranion]]''.<ref>{{RK|V8}}</ref><ref name=PE49>{{PE|17}}
column2: p. 49</ref> A signification given of ''asëa'' is "name of plant '[[athelas]]'".<ref>{{PE|Eldarin}}

column1: The meaning and etymology of ''asëa'' is a matter of debate. In [[1998]]
column2: William Cloud Hicklin claimed to have "ongoing discussion about the origins of [the word [[athelas]]]" with [[Christopher Tolkien]]
column3: and wrote in a forum message that:

column1: ''a very late note [by Tolkien] (1970 or later) says that Asea [...] was the name in Quenya, regularly adapted and compounded with -las in Sindarin.  The plant was known to the medical loremasters of the Noldor. The root is *ATHAYA, 'helpful, kindly, beneficial.''<ref>[http://groups.google.com/group/rec.arts.books.tolkien/msg/3fad9c3c879f5a2c Athelas] (message from William Cloud Hicklin
Hicklin's assertion has attracted a widespread attention on the Internet
column2: <ref>[http://forums.theonering.com/viewtopic.php?p=2854688 Annotated LotR Project: Flight to the Ford] at [http://forums.theonering.com Forums.theonering.com] (accessed 14 May 2011)</ref><ref>[http://groups.yahoo.com/group/elfling/message/32497 Message 32497] (dated 4 October 2005) at [[Elfling]] (accessed 14 May 2011)</ref><ref>[http://www.tuckborough.net/plants.html Plants & Trees] (cf. Athelas) at [http://www.tuckborough.net/index.htm The Thain's Book] (accessed 14 May 2011)</ref> and was reprinted in the journal ''[[Tyalië Tyelelliéva]]'' [[Tyalië Tyelelliéva 15|No. 15]] (p. 31).<ref>Lisa Star
column3: "[http://www.reocities.com/tyalie/unpub.html A List of Tolkien's Unpublished and Slightly Published Manuscripts]" (dated August 2002) at [http://www.reocities.com/ Reocities.com] (accessed 14 May 2011)</ref> Hicklin's suggested etymology has also been picked up by [[Helge Fauskanger]] in his "Quenya-to-English wordlist"
column4: where ''asëa'' is said to be an adjective meaning "beneficial
column6: kindly" derived from root ATHAYA.<ref>[http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/quen-eng.htm Quettaparma Quenyallo] at [http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/ Ardalambion] (accessed 14 May 2011)</ref><ref>[http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/wordlists.htm Quenya Wordlists] at [http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/ Ardalambion] (accessed 14 May 2011)</ref><ref  group="note">This is given by [[Helge Fauskanger]] as the first meaning of ''asëa''. The second meaning is given as "2) asëa (þ) noun
column7: name of the healing plant called in Sindarin ''athelas''"

column1: Another mention of the existence of an unpublished etymology of ''athelas''/''asëa'' occurred in ''[[The Lord of the Rings: A Reader's Companion]]'' ([[2005]]/[[2008]])
column2: where the authors referred to a claim by [[Arden R. Smith]]. Here it was written that the first element in ''athelas'' is connected with Quenya ''asëa''.<ref name=RC183>{{HM|RC}}

column1: With the publication of [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]]'s manuscript "Words
column2: Phrases & Passages in ''The Lord of the Rings''" in [[2007]]
column4: and editor [[Christopher Gilson]] wrote in a comment that this etymology is the source of the claim in ''[[The Lord of the Rings: A Reader's Companion]]''.

column1: Since Tolkien's manuscript date from the late 1950s and early 1960s (and does not include any mention of the root ATHAYA)
column2: Hicklin's claim of an unpublished etymology dating from the 1970s remains unverified in published sources.

column1: In his analysis of the Quenya words in "Words
column2: Phrases & Passages in ''The Lord of the Rings''"
column3: Petri Tikka has tentatively suggested that ''asëa'' could mean "foil" (gloss followed by a question mark).<ref>Petri Tikka
column4: "[http://www.petritikka.com/elvish/PE17.html Quenya words in Parma Eldalambaron 17]" at [http://www.petritikka.com/elvish/ Men Eldalambínen: A Place in Elvish] (accessed 14 May 2011)</ref><ref group="note">Tikka's reasoning apparently stems from a literal translation of ''[[asëa aranion]]'' as "[[athelas|kingsfoil]]". Tolkien's translation of ''asëa aranion'' as "asëa of the Kings" is given in {{PE|17}}
column6: and the note which says "''athelas'' 'kingsfoil' appears on p. 49.</ref>
